articles.headline: Trump Returns North Korea to List of State Sponsors of Terrorism
articles.snippet: North Korea had been removed from the list under the George W. Bush administration in an attempt to salvage negotiations for a nuclear deal.
articles.abstract: North Korea had been removed from the list under the George W. Bush administration in an attempt to salvage negotiations for a nuclear deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday officially designated North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism, a provocative diplomatic move that he said was aimed at drastically increasing pressure on the rogue nation to abandon its pursuit of nuclear weapons.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: In Crisis, Angela Merkel Prefers Elections to Minority Rule
articles.snippet: Chancellor Angela Merkel says she would prefer a new round of elections to leading a minority government, if the quest for a majority coalition fails.
articles.abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel says she would prefer a new round of elections to leading a minority government, if the quest for a majority coalition fails.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany faced the greatest crisis of her career on Monday after negotiations to form a new government collapsed, shaking a country that is Europe’s political and economic anchor.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Yellen Will Leave Federal Reserve Next Year
articles.snippet: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said she would leave the Fed when a successor is installed. She could have remained as a governor until 2024.
articles.abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said she would leave the Fed when a successor is installed. She could have remained as a governor until 2024.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said on Monday that she would step down from the Fed’s board at the same time that she ends her term as chairwoman.

articles.headline: Justice Department Sues to Block AT&T-Time Warner Merger
articles.snippet: A lawsuit to block the merger sets up a showdown over the first blockbuster acquisition to come before the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit to block the merger sets up a showdown over the first blockbuster acquisition to come before the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department sued to block AT&T’s $85.4 billion bid for Time Warner on Monday, setting up a showdown over the first blockbuster acquisition to be considered by the Trump administration and drawing limits on corporate power in the fast-evolving media landscape.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Fanatics, Maker of Sports Apparel, Thrives by Seizing the Moment
articles.snippet: The company has carved out a lucrative niche by securing valuable licensing rights and moving quickly to capitalize on surges in fan demand.
articles.abstract: The company has carved out a lucrative niche by securing valuable licensing rights and moving quickly to capitalize on surges in fan demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa. — This fall, as some of the N.F.L.’s corporate partners fretted about the league’s handling of its players kneeling during the national anthem, the sports merchandise company Fanatics pounced.

articles.headline: Indian Automaker’s Plant Is Latest Sign of Detroit Comeback
articles.snippet: Mahindra will open the area’s first new vehicle assembly factory in 25 years, building off-road vehicles. The move may signal larger ambitions in the American market.
articles.abstract: Mahindra will open the area’s first new vehicle assembly factory in 25 years, building off-road vehicles. The move may signal larger ambitions in the American market.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — It has been years since Detroit, birthplace of the American auto industry, was a steady producer of the manufacturing jobs that defined it as the Motor City. But its comeback is entering a new phase.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Ends Temporary Protection for Haitians
articles.snippet: A program that let 59,000 Haitians remain in the United States after a 2010 earthquake will end in July 2019.
articles.abstract: A program that let 59,000 Haitians remain in the United States after a 2010 earthquake will end in July 2019.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is ending a humanitarian program that has allowed some 59,000 Haitians to live and work in the United States since an earthquake ravaged their country in 2010, Homeland Security officials said on Monday.

articles.headline: Trump Halted These Hunt Trophies. Elephant Lovers Will Never Forget It.
articles.snippet: Just why the president shelved his own administration’s rule on bringing hunt trophies into the country — a weighty query — is the elephant in the room.
articles.abstract: Just why the president shelved his own administration’s rule on bringing hunt trophies into the country — a weighty query — is the elephant in the room.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maybe it was the memory of a long-ago childhood visit to the zoo. Maybe it was a sense of loyalty to the symbol of his political party.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: C.E.O. Deficit Fears Dissolve With the Prospect of Corporate Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: In 2012, business leaders warned against the looming debt disaster. Now, with corporate tax cuts on the table, those concerns have been put aside.
articles.abstract: In 2012, business leaders warned against the looming debt disaster. Now, with corporate tax cuts on the table, those concerns have been put aside.
articles.lead_paragraph: In mid-October 2012, Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, hosted a luncheon on the 49th floor of the firm’s Park Avenue headquarters. The guest list was a boldface roll call of corporate executives and policymakers: Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, David M. Cote of Honeywell, the Democratic senator Mark Warner of Virginia and the Republican senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, among others.

articles.headline: They Stayed Put, but Their City Disappeared
articles.snippet: In Syria’s capital, those who remain wonder why they’re still there when so many friends have packed up, died or vanished.
articles.abstract: In Syria’s capital, those who remain wonder why they’re still there when so many friends have packed up, died or vanished.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — On a cool evening in early November, in a back room of the Damascus Opera House, a women’s choir was rehearsing an old favorite, a sunny ballad from a childhood cartoon. When they reached the chorus — “How sweet it is to live in one house, how sweet to live in one hometown” — one of the singers, Safana Baqleh, began to weep into her hands.

articles.headline: Patent ‘Trolls’ Recede as Threat to Innovation. Will Justices Change That?
articles.snippet: Created to keep invalid claims from hurting companies, consumers and the economy, a government panel faces an existential threat in a case before the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: Created to keep invalid claims from hurting companies, consumers and the economy, a government panel faces an existential threat in a case before the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August, real estate agents in Texas fended off a company’s demands for royalty payments for a feature of many websites: the ability to show prospective home buyers where local schools, parks and grocery stores are. Administrative law judges at the United States Patent and Trademark Office found that the patent claims were simply not valid.
